data.title: TJX Delivers Q4 Beat, Analysts Praise 'Notable MarMaxx Strength'
data.description:
Shares of TJX Companies Inc (NYSE:TJX) rose in early trading on Thursday,after the company reported upbeat fourth-quarter results.

Here are the key analyst insights:

Check out other analyst stock ratings.

BTIG: TJX reported total sales of $17.7 billion, up 8.5% year-on-year, ahead of estimates of 4.2%, Drbul said in a note. The company's total comps grew 5%, higher than the 3% expectation, "driven by increases in both traffic and ticket across the portfolio," he wrote.

Sales growth and gross margin expansion drove earnings to $1.43 per share, topping consensus of $1.38 per share, the analyst stated. TJX announced plans to hike dividend by 13% and repurchase shares worth around $2.6 billion in fiscal 2027, he added.

Telsey Advisory Group: TJX reported "another strong quarterly performance," with higher-than-expected earnings, driven by strong sales growth and gross margin expansion, Telsey said. The company's performance was supported by "notable strength at MarMaxx," she added.

"Despite ongoing macro challenges, TJX continues to demonstrate resilience and consistency," the analyst wrote. Management announced first-quarter and fiscal 2026 guidance below consensus estimates, which is "consistent with its past practice of issuing conservative guidance in an uncertain environment," she further stated.

TJX Price Action: Shares of TJX Companies had risen by 1.52% to $158.08 at the time of publication on Thursday.

Image: Shutterstock

data.title: Here's How Much $1000 Invested In HCA Healthcare 15 Years Ago Would Be Worth Today
data.description:
HCA Healthcare (NYSE:HCA) has outperformed the market over the past 15 years by 9.22% on an annualized basis producing an average annual return of 20.83%. Currently, HCA Healthcare has a market capitalization of $118.45 billion.

Buying $1000 In HCA: If an investor had bought $1000 of HCA stock 15 years ago, it would be worth $17,075.76 today based on a price of $529.69 for HCA at the time of writing.

HCA Healthcare's Performance Over Last 15 Years

Finally -- what's the point of all this? The key insight to take from this article is to note how much of a difference compounded returns can make in your cash growth over a period of time.

data.title: People Say They're Getting 'Crushed' By Electric Bills Without Touching Their Thermostats. 'The Math For The Next Few Years Is Pretty Grim'
data.description:
Homeowners across the country say they are getting “crushed” by electric bills this winter, even though they haven't adjusted their thermostats. On Reddit, frustrated residents shared stories of bills jumping hundreds of dollars compared with last year.

One homeowner wrote that after digging into the numbers, “the math for the next few years is pretty grim,” pointing to newly approved rate hikes for this year and beyond.

Why Bills Are Spiking

For many, the shock isn't just higher energy use during cold snaps. It's the fees.

Don't Miss:

  • Bad Ads Live Forever — See How This AI Helps Fortune 1000 Brands Avoid Them
  • This Energy Storage Company Already Has $185M in Contracts—Shares Are Still Available

Several homeowners said their actual electricity usage was flat or even lower than last year, yet their bills rose 20%, 30% or more. One person reported using 20% less electricity but paying 33% more. Another said their bill doubled in a one-bedroom trailer to $400.

A common complaint centers on delivery charges and add-on fees. “Sometimes my electrical actual commodity cost is LESS THAN the delivery fee and other add-ons,” one commenter wrote. “It’s purely ridiculous.” Another said $130 of a $200 bill was delivery charges alone.

In the Northeast, some reported paying 25 cents to 44 cents per kilowatt-hour once supply and delivery are combined. In other parts of the country, rates remain closer to 8 cents to 12 cents. 

Cold weather is part of the story. Several states experienced prolonged freezes this winter. Heat pump owners were hit especially hard when auxiliary electric heat kicked in during subfreezing temperatures. But many insist that weather alone doesn't explain everything.

“I used less kWh last year compared to the previous year but my bill is still higher,” one homeowner wrote, blaming rising base rates and new fees.

Trending: Own the Characters, Not Just the Content: Inside a Fast-Growing Pre-IPO IP Company

The AI Data Center Debate

Some commenters argue the increases are tied to infrastructure upgrades needed to power massive AI data centers.

“Look at AI data centers gobbling up energy and we're all paying for it,” one person wrote. “It’s disgusting.”

The original poster claimed utilities are passing along the cost of billions in grid upgrades, adding that customers are effectively subsidizing new infrastructure while utilities receive state-approved profit margins.

Others pushed back, saying the electric grid has needed upgrades for decades. Rising interest rates, wildfire prevention projects and long-delayed maintenance are also driving capital spending.

Still, frustration runs deep. “We should not be paying for city-size data center infrastructure none of us asked for,” one commenter wrote. “Data centers need to pay for their own construction and utilities.”

Some homeowners are looking for ways to offset the pain. Solar installations, insulation upgrades and switching suppliers were frequently mentioned. Others suggested attending public utility commission meetings, though many expressed skepticism about whether regulators truly push back on utilities.

Can You Hedge Rising Energy Costs

As artificial intelligence expands, electricity demand is expected to climb. That could result in continued infrastructure investment and, potentially, higher base rates.

For households feeling squeezed, rising utility bills are also a reminder to review the bigger financial picture, especially for those nearing retirement.

“For now, a lot of people probably aren't even aware of the increase,” one commenter summed up the mood. “But it barely matters that you ‘know' it because it's not like you have a choice here. There is only ONE utility provider. A for-profit, privately owned company.”

For households already stretched by mortgages, insurance and food costs, even a $100 jump can hurt. As one person put it after opening a $400 bill in a small home: “That is not acceptable.”

Image: Shutterstock

data.title: Warren Buffett's Favorite Soda Is Now More 'Expensive' Than Microsoft
data.description:
Investors expect AI giants to command the market's richest valuations. But right now, Warren Buffett's favorite soda is trading at a premium to one of the most important technology companies in the world.

Coke's Valuation Quietly Surpasses Microsoft

Yet investors are now paying a higher premium for Coca-Cola's earnings.

This suggests valuation isn't being driven purely by growth — but by certainty.

Buffett's $28 Billion Bet Reflects The Power Of Predictability

That consistency reflects Coca-Cola's most valuable trait: predictability. Its global scale, pricing power, and recurring demand make its earnings unusually stable — even when macro conditions shift.

Markets Are Quietly Rewarding Stability Again

Microsoft remains one of the market's most dominant companies. But Coca-Cola's premium valuation reveals a subtle shift in investor psychology.

In uncertain environments, stability can command a premium over growth.

Buffett recognized that decades ago.

Now, the market appears to be rediscovering it.

Photo: Shutterstock
